bestBHT.bht: Jesus, in his teaching, used a Rabbinical method of questioning before beginning a discourse, an example that all teachers should follow. In his efforts to adapt his instructions, he included his disciples and the hearers in a consultative manner. By utilizing plain and striking illustrations, Jesus communicated clearer ideas about the Gospel dispensation and the success of the Gospel. His humble approach and tactful questioning engaged the audience and set an example for ministers teaching about the kingdom of God.

Henry Alford: This Rabbinical method of questioning before beginning a discourse is also found in Luke, ver. 18.
The condescending plural, which embraces the disciples, in their work of preaching and teaching.
It gives all teachers an example, to what they may liken the Kingdom of God.
Albert Barnes: “This shows the great solicitude which Jesus had to adapt his instructions to the capacity of his disciples.”
“He sought out the most plain and striking illustrations - an example which should be followed by all the ministers of the gospel.”
“To do this the following things are necessary in a minister: Humility.”
Marvin Vincent: In what parable shall we set it forth?"
Note the we, taking the hearers, with a fine tact, into consultation.
Philip Schaff: Opening a discussion with a question seems to have been a usual mode with Jewish teachers.
Here our Lord graciously includes His disciples (‘we’) who were also to teach about the kingdom of God.
Christ’s way of teaching is still to be followed.
Archibald T. Robertson: How shall we liken?" (Πως ομοιωσωμεν?) Deliberative first aorist subjunctive. This question alone in Mark.
In what parable shall we set it forth?" (εν τιν αυτην παραβολη θωμεν?) Deliberative second aorist subjunctive. The graphic question draws the interest of the hearers (we) by fine tact.

Luke 13:18 retains the double question which Matthew 13:31 does not have, though he has it in a very different context, probably an illustration of Christ's favourite sayings often repeated to different audiences as is true of all teachers and preachers.
John Gill: Still continuing his discourse on this subject, and in order to convey to the minds of his disciples clearer ideas of the Gospel dispensation, the success of the Gospel, and the usefulness of their ministration of it, for their encouragement, how unpromising soever things might then be.
It was usual with the Jewish doctors, when about to illustrate anything in a parabolical way to begin with such like questions; as, למה הדבר דומה, 'to what is this thing like'?
When the answer is to such or such thing, as here.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, in his teaching, used a Rabbinical method of questioning before beginning a discourse, an example that all teachers should follow. In Mark 4:30, Jesus includes his disciples and the hearers in a consultative manner, seeking to adapt his instructions to their capacity. This shows his great solicitude and the humble approach necessary for ministers to effectively teach the kingdom of God. His method of using plain and striking illustrations remains relevant, as he sought to convey clearer ideas of the Gospel dispensation and the success of the Gospel. By opening the discussion with a question, Jesus engaged the audience's interest and showed his tact as a teacher.

In his teaching, Jesus employed a Rabbinical method of questioning before beginning a discourse, a practice that all teachers should follow. He demonstrates great solicitude in seeking to adapt his instructions to the capacity of his disciples and the hearers, inviting them into consultation with him. Jesus utilized plain and striking illustrations to convey clearer ideas of the Gospel dispensation and the success of the Gospel. His humble approach and tactful questioning engaged the audience and remain relevant for ministers teaching about the kingdom of God.

Jesus employed a Rabbinical method of questioning before beginning his discourse, including his disciples and the hearers in the consultation. This reflects his great solicitude to adapt his teachings to their capacity. By using plain and striking illustrations, Jesus conveyed clearer ideas about the Gospel dispensation and the success of the Gospel. His humble approach and tactful questioning engaged the audience and set an example for all teachers and ministers of the kingdom of God.
